summary: This document appears to be notes or a summary from a WebEx meeting on November 18, 2021, involving Gary Stein, Paul Kane, and Keni Ukabiala. The discussion centers on the admissions and record-keeping practices of a school (likely Professional Children's School - PCS), specifically regarding a 1998 application (GX 761) and its relevance to a legal case. The context suggests this is part of discovery or preparation for a trial related to the Epstein case.

events.title: WebEx Meeting on School Records
events.description: A WebEx meeting was held involving Gary Stein, Paul Kane, and Keni Ukabiala to review a pseudonym order and discuss the admissions process and record-keeping of a school (PCS), specifically regarding a 1998 application (GX 761) relevant to a case.

events.title: Submission of School Application GX 761
events.description: An application to the Professional Children's School (PCS) from 1998 is referenced as exhibit GX 761. The document survived digitization of records around 2011-2012 and is a subject of discussion for trial.

events.title: Digitization of Student Permanent Files
events.description: The student permanent files at PCS were digitized around this time. The 1998 application (GX 761) had not been purged and was included in this digitization.

keyFacts: The document records a 2021 WebEx meeting discussing a pseudonym order and a school's (PCS) connection to a case, prompted by a parent's call and a Daily Beast article.
Paul Kane, a school administrator, detailed the admissions and record-keeping processes at PCS from the 1990s to the present, including the digitization of records around 2011-2012.
A specific 1998 school application (marked as GX 761) is a key piece of evidence; it was preserved in the student's digitized permanent file and is intended to be used at trial.

PCS typically keeps records for 6 years as per NY State Association of Independent Schools guidelines, after which they are normally shredded, but permanent files (with transcripts, etc.) are kept indefinitely.
The document is subject to a protective order, indicating the sensitive nature of the information discussed regarding the case.
